div1.p: IN THE SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITES STATES.
IN THE MATTER OF THE UNLAWFUL DENTENTION OF SEVENTY-THREE HINDOO ALIENS.
No. 2532 ASSIGNMENT OF ERROR

Come now the petitioning aliens and file the following assignment of errors on which they will rely in the prosecution of their appeal in the above entitled cause to the Supreme Court of the United States from the District Court of the Western Dis- trict of Washington.
I.
The court erred in refusing to grant the writ of habeas corpus.
II.

The court erred in holding the decision of the immigration department final, and that the court would not inter- fere to see justice done where injustice was alleged, as the allegation was made that there was no evidence and that the con- struction of a statute was involved and a legal matter was at issue as to the construction of Section 20, and in holding the immigration decision final and in refusing to examine the evi- dence for the purpose of testing the correctness of petitioners'
allegations
III.
The court erred in refusing to find that the petitioners had been deprived of their constitutional rights under Articles 5, 6, 8, and 14 of the amendments of the Constitution of the United States.
IV.

The court erred in not holding that the examination at Seattle, Washington, after a due and proper exami- nation by the immigration authorities at Manila, after resi- dence in the Philippine Islands for several years, was not an improper examination and an abuse of authority and discre- tion.
V.
The court erred in refusing to hold that the exami- nation and admission at Manila, a regular port of entry, was not final and sufficient.
VI.

The court erred in refusing to find that the warrant of arrest on authority of which the aliens were threatened with deportation, was not faulty and contrary to law and not a sufficient warrant on which to deport the aliens under author- ity of the Act of February 20, 1907, and Section 20 thereof.
VII.

The court erred in refusing to find that the examination was not fair and impartial and in refusing and failing to find that the immigration authorities went outside of the law and acted contrary to law in issuing the warrant and in threatening to deport.
VIII.

That the court erred in refusing to find and failing to find that the immigration department violated the Act of February 20, 1907, and particularly Section 20 thereof, in that no evidence was ever produced show- ing that the aliens came within the confines or within the provisions of said law.
IX.

The court erred in refusing to find that the aliens had never violated any of the provisions of the said Act of February, 20, 1907, and refusing to fina that the immigration department officials transcended the bound of their authority in holding that the aliens had violated the provisions of the Act and came within the provisions thereof.
X.
The court erred in failing to find that the de- cision of the immigration department and the issuing of the warrants was all contrary to law and in direct violation of the Act of February 20, 1907.
XI

The court erred in failing to find that the
Commissioner of Immigration and the Secretary of Labor, in denying petitioners right to land, when there was no evidence on which to base said decision, was not an abuse of authority and discretion.
XII.
The court erred in failing to find that the petitioners had once been duly examined and passed and could not again be lawfully examined.
XIII.

The court erred in failing to find that the petitioners had never become public charges and had never entered the country unlawfully or surreptitious- ly as intended in the Act of February 20, 1907, and there- fore were not subject to arrest and deportation.
XIV.
The court erred in refusing to find that there was no proper, material or substantial evidence, showing the aliens to come within the confines of Act of February 20, 1907.
XV.
The court erred in refusing and failing to find that as the aliens had lived under the protection of the American flag in the Philippine Islands, their detention at Seattle, Washington, was improper.
XVI.

The court erred in failing to find that when the aliens testified that they had been properly ex- amined and passed by the immigration authority at Manila, and when they presented official documents stamped by the
immigration department in Manila, showing them to have been properly landed there, that that was sufficient proof to demand at lest some proof, showing a surrep- titious landing or an unlawful entry at Manila, in order to come within the Act of February 20, 1907 of the Immigration Act.
XVII.
The court erred in failing to find that the warrants were improperly issued contrary to law and erred in not quashing the same.
XVIII.

The court erred in failing to find that the four aliens, Moola Singh, Ram Singh, Ali Bux and Boggu Khan, having had certificates, were not entitled to immediate landing at Seattle, and that they were not improperly detained at said port.
XIX.
The court erred in failing to find that the petitioners had had no hearing on the ground on which the exclusion was based.
XX.
The court erred in failing to find that the aliens were not amenable to the law which was the basis for the issuance of the warrants.
XXI.

The court erred in finding that the district court had no jurisdiction to examine into the matter, as
the aliens had shown that no evidence was produced on the ground of the deportation, and that there was a question of law involved in that they were not amenable to the Act of February 20, 1907, and that Section 20, on authority of which they were arrested, did not apply to them.
XXII.
The court erred in failing to grant the writ of habeas corpus and in failing to release the peti- tioners.
XXIII.
The court erred in refusing to order the aliens released and in quashing the warrants or arrest, as be- ing unlawfully issued.
XXLV.
The court erred in failing to find that there had been no hearing accorded the aliens on the ground of the deportation.
XXV.

The court erred in failing to find that the testimony, under oath, of the aliens and the exhibits furnished by aliens, showing them to have been in the hands of the immigration officers at Manila did not over- come any presumption as indicated in the ruling of the department under Rule 14, sub-division 4.
XXVI.
The court erred in failing to find that Section 20 was mandatory.
XXVII.

The court erred in failing to find that the immigration authorities abused their authority and they did not fairly exercise their discretion in ordering deportation of aliens when no evidence was produced on the point of the deportation.
XXVIII.
The court erred in failing to find that the allegation of unlawful entry was not proven and no evidence was produced on the point.
XXIX.

The court erred in failing to find that Rule 22, sub-division 2 of the Immigration Act, had not been complied with, as said provision requires that the best evidence should be obtained and as the government could have obtained the evidence from their own records at Manila, and as they produced no evidence.
XXX.

The court erred in failing to find that the immigration authorities had not complied with Rule 22. Section 4, in that that provision provides for the confine- ment of aliens in alms houses, hospitals and jails, and that no such proof was ever offered.
XXXI.

The court erred in failing to find that under Rule 14, Sub division 4 of the Immigration Rules of November 15, 1911, that the immigration officials vio-
lated said provision and that said presumption did not apply to the aliens in this case, as a lawful entry at Manila had been shown and no evidence introduced to over- come said definite testimony.
XXXII.

The court erred in failing to find that Section 25 had no application in these cases and refers, so far as the finality of decision goes, to cases where the aliens were making their first entry and not those resident in the country, as in this case.
XXXIII.
The court erred in failing to find that the violation of the Act as is outlined in Section 21 refers to Section 20 as to unlawful entry and becoming charges, which were not proven in these cases.
XXXIV.
The court erred in failing to strictly construe Section 20.
XXXV.
The court erred in failing to release the aliens as prayed for in their petition.

WHEREFORE the said petitioners pray that the judgment of the said trial court be reversed and that the said District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division, be directed to release the aliens and that they be released from custody and given their freedom, in accordamce with justice and law.
Herbert W. Meyers Attorney for petitioners.
No. 2532 Tx
IN THE SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES.
IN THE MATTER OF THE UNLAWFUL DETENTION OF SEVENTY- THREE HINDOO ALIENS.
ASSIGNMENT OF ERRORS.
Received Copy Sept 30, 1913 EBBrockway Asst U.S. Atty
FILED IN THE U.S. District Court, Western Dist. of Washington. OCT 4 1913 FRANK L. CROSBY, Clerk, By BD Wright Deputy
HERBERT W. MEYERS ATTORNEY AT LAW 430-431-432-433 PIONEER BUILDING PHONE MAIN 1278 SEATTLE, WASH.
MERCHANTS PRINTING CO., TIMES BLDG., SEATTLE
